Had to generate a new token.  The old token was created when our NPM account had 2FA enabled _for publishing_, so we couldn't publish using the token without 2FA.  Apparently NPM uses 2FA on API tokens too, in a way that I've never seen before.  Oh well.  I've updated our NPM settings to only have 2FA enabled for "authorization" ("For example, logging into npmjs.com or through the command line") but _disabled_ for "publishing" ("All of the above plus updating and publishing packages to the registry").

After changing that setting, the old token still didn't work to publish (still required 2FA code), so this is a new code generated after changing that setting.  (Encrypted for Travis as documented, obvs.)

Don't search escaped HTML text Before this change, if you tried to search for "&" to match "Stuff & Nonsense", what we would do is html-escape _both_ things and compare the escaped strings. This works fine in the case where you just type "&". However, if you type "mp", that will match the html entity "&" in the middle of the html-escaped text we're comparing it to. Which is incorrect. Additionally, we highlight our "matched" result. When we do, we break up the entity so that the resulting HTML looks like: Stuff & Nonsense And you get to see what basically looks like garbage on the screen. ![screen garbage](https://camo.githubusercontent.com/b5e384f3f622f3560739c287c481e05a7b0668af/68747470733a2f2f646c2e64726f70626f7875736572636f6e74656e742e636f6d2f7370612f7470786279757478626b747069347a2f6c7566336c7835792e706e67) This commit fixes all of that by just comparing the actual text of things. We avoid the problem previous addressed in #2254 by escaping each piece of the to-be-highlighted option text before assembling it into HTML.

Allow detached head when parsing master ref.

If we have checked out a commit instead of a branch name, git is in what’s known as “detached head” state.

This is what Travis does all the time.

This means that we were never considered to be on the branch “master”, and therefore were never publishing bower-chosen.

We can tweak the git command we’re calling to support either checked out branch names or detached heads — as long as we’re at the commit for a commit that is the head of master, we’re peachykeen!
